Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 07:34PM PinPDX wrote: The straps are adjustable.  If you decide to check out the website (see link in my first post) there is an area where you can send the maker of the bra any questions you have.   That is what I did and after emailing with her, I decided to try the bra.
Posts.Title: A Great Bra PinPDX River_Rat

Posts.Content: PinPDX wrote: I want to share some information about a REALLY comfortable bra.  I have had bilateral mastectomies and have been searching for almost 3 years for a bra that isn't tight and doesn't irritate my scars.  I have tried regular bras with and w/o pockets sewn in, mastectomy bras (the worst!) soft, stretchy cotton bras with pockets (too tight and hot) and "Handful" sports bras (not bad) but Zee Bra! is my new find and worth raving about!  The web site is easy to use and the people who make these are incredibly helpful and really nice.  The bra is made out of a very silky soft material, has pockets even tho' not made for mastectomy gals and comes with various sizes of inserts. The bras have NO elastic but still manage to stay in place well.  They are made for small breasted women but, as I said, work well for me with no breasts!  They are coming out soon with bras with bigger openings for the pockets, but I managed to get my silicone "biggest boob" prostheses in there.  I am so excited about this find I just had to share the news.  Here's the site: www.thezeebra.com  Dx 5/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage II, Grade 1, 0/1 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: A Great Bra PinPDX River_Rat

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2011 01:07PM PinPDX wrote: Maybe a second opinion would be a good idea.  A ductogram makes sense to me.  I do know that yellow/bloody discharge is not normal so needs some sort of evaluation.  The discharge fluid can also be looked at under the microscope for abnormal cells.  I also would ask how big the excisional biopsy has to be...  you have so many ducts, I would think a person could nurse on that side but I am not a breast expert.  I did have an excisional biopsy on one of my breasts (not near the nipple) and was able to nurse both my children on that side w/o problems.  The most important thing is to make sure you do what is best for YOUR health at this point!
Posts.Title: quick question neochiq neochiq

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2011 07:56PM PinPDX wrote: I do use my prostheses in the bra for some tops but it is a little hard to get the silicone forms (my largest foobs) into the pocket.  The owner of the company tells me that they are soon coming out with the same bra but with bigger openings to make it easier for women who want to put their own prostheses in the bra.  The bra was originally made for women with smaller breasts and comes with its own removable pads. You could put almost anything in there though. I think so many women who've had mastectomies were buying the bras and asking for this adaptation that they decided to make one for us!    I wear it with the "forms" that it comes with if I just want to look "small breasted" and it works for me but I am fairly thin and used to looking "small".  The bra is just so comfortable, it is like wearing nothing.  Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: A Great Bra PinPDX River_Rat

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2011 04:45PM PinPDX wrote: I,too, wish I had found this conversation long ago!  I am also post bilateral mastectomies and until recently discovering the ZeeBra, had given up finding anything that didn't feel too tight or irritate my scars.  The ZeeBra works for me, even slightly better with the heavier silicon forms which prevent riding up.  It is amazingly comfortable.  I had been using Handful bras for the gym and still do.  What I wanted to tell everyone is that if you like or want to try ZeeBras, they are coming out soon with a beige model which will have bigger openings to fit prostheses into.  Once I try one, I'll let you know how it works!  Thanks especially to Erica, for your web site, I am so happy to find it and it is very helpful.
Posts.Title: New Bra jbau Aug242007

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2011 05:36PM - edited Feb 19, 2011 05:44PM by PinPDX Hi JanS, yes I wear my handful bras exclusively for the gym.  I actually bought the first one at a running shoe store that sold sports bras, which was nice because I could try it on.  I am a 34-36 and found the medium size a good fit.  I find that it looks just like my old compression bra made me look, i.e, a bit flatter than with a real bra but definitely passable for the gym.  The openings for the inserts are big so I am sure you could fit a bigger form in there if desired.  They come with a little mesh bag and I just put the bra in there - don't even remove the pad sometimes - and wash in the machine but hang to dry and let the pads air-dry on top of the dryer.  They wash up very nicely and they never seem to smell after exercise so I wear them several x before washing!  The inserts are sturdy as well with a little more padding on the lower side.  Hope this helps!
Posts.Title: New Bra jbau Aug242007

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2011 05:39PM PinPDX wrote: Oh but I meant to mention also that I have had bilateral mastectomies so it was easy to look symmetric in the bra.  I was also not super big before.  If your remaining breast is large, it might be more of a challenge so perhaps seeing if you could find a sporting goods store that sells them to try one on would be worth a try...
Posts.Title: New Bra jbau Aug242007

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2011 11:54AM - edited Feb 22, 2011 11:55AM by PinPDX Jan: I would love to know if it works!  One other thing occurred to me.  During the year between my first mx and the 2nd one (when I had one breast) I continued to wear my compression sports bras to work out (They are the ones made by "Champion") and I would just slip one of those triangular foam forms in on the mx side and it look for all the world "normal" and never seemed to budge.  So if the "Handful" bra doesn't fit, that might be something to consider...

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2011 07:39PM PinPDX wrote: Hi robinlbe, You can order a ZeeBra from the web site which is very informative and easy to use.  Yes, it is a little price ($40.00) but I have to say, it IS REALLY different and amazingly comfortable.  When I clicked to ask a question, I got an email from the woman who started the company.  She sent the bra right out with a sweet note and included extra pads to adjust the size with.  I ended up actually sqeezing my $600 "big boobs" into it since - just like you - I'd given up on wearing them!  (At one point I even gave them to my daughter to cushion raw eggs she was dropping out of our second story window in a physics experiment... but I digress.)  I really like the gal who invented this bra - she told me they are coming up with a new one with bigger openings for BC users.  I hope you like it as much as I do so far... don't get rid of those old tops yet!!  Here's the web address: www.thezeebra.com
Posts.Title: No reconstruction- Happy w/your decision? marlee1 quietpools

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2011 03:37PM PinPDX wrote: It is so interesting to read this thread.  I can identify with all the feelings.  Having seen reconstructed breasts prior to my own surgery (I work in health care), I felt they looked and felt unnatural and it didn't seem worth the trouble and added discomfort.  After my first mastectomy in 2008, what bothered me most was the asymmetry!  I wished my surgeon had been willing to do both at the same time.  Then a year later I got BC in my other breast - yea! (ha ha) and it was a no brainer to get rid of that one as well and be symmetric, even if flat.  These past 2 years have been a journey of trying various prostheses and bras, and, believe me, I have tried them all.  I mostly go bra-less and find that many tops camouflage very well and folks don't notice.  My latest greatest discovery is a bra called "Zee Bra!" which has got to be the absolute most comfortable bra I have had pre or post mastectomies!  I use it w/my silicone boobs and it somehow prevents the sweating and heavy feeling.  It also comes with its own variety of inserts for making your bust as big or small as you'd like!  I am still working through the self-consciousness of my body when naked; I used to have no problem with that at all, but I am getting there and still don't have one bit of regret at being breast-free.  Hope that helps.
Posts.Title: No reconstruction- Happy w/your decision? marlee1 quietpools
